body_html:
I have ran the python2 and 3 builds with this PR. After we do "pip install virtualenv" `$PYTHON_BIN_PATH -m virtualenv` command seems to work on my machine on all the cases I tested. It looks like "venv" is just "commonly together with python3 distros" but we can always install and use virtualenv.
…
On Sun, Dec 10, 2017 at 5:41 PM, Shanqing Cai ***@***.***> wrote: Ah - that's unfortunate. Sorry I didn't try the PR with tf-nightly jobs. But I'm still not sure if this PR is going to fix all cases. For example, if $PYTHON_BIN_PATH points to a python 3 version, the module name used after -m should be venv, but not virtualenv. — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. body_text:
I have ran the python2 and 3 builds with this PR.
After we do "pip install virtualenv" `$PYTHON_BIN_PATH -m virtualenv`
command seems to work on my machine on all the cases I tested.
It looks like "venv" is just "commonly together with python3 distros" but
we can always install and use virtualenv.
…
On Sun, Dec 10, 2017 at 5:41 PM, Shanqing Cai ***@***.***> wrote:
 Ah - that's unfortunate. Sorry I didn't try the PR with tf-nightly jobs.
 But I'm still not sure if this PR is going to fix all cases. For example,
 if $PYTHON_BIN_PATH points to a python 3 version, the module name used
 after -m should be venv, but not virtualenv.

 —

body:
I have ran the python2 and 3 builds with this PR.
After we do "pip install virtualenv" `$PYTHON_BIN_PATH -m virtualenv`
command seems to work on my machine on all the cases I tested.
It looks like "venv" is just "commonly together with python3 distros" but
we can always install and use virtualenv.

On Sun, Dec 10, 2017 at 5:41 PM, Shanqing Cai <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> Ah - that's unfortunate. Sorry I didn't try the PR with tf-nightly jobs.
> But I'm still not sure if this PR is going to fix all cases. For example,
> if $PYTHON_BIN_PATH points to a python 3 version, the module name used
> after -m should be venv, but not virtualenv.
>
> —
